title: Under the hood: The chemistry of cars - Cynthia Chubbuck

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of a car's cooling system?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb and dissipate heat from the engine block

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the engine's horsepower

options.label: C
options.text: To improve the car's fuel efficiency

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the car's emissions

multiple-choice.question: Why is water not an ideal choice for a car's cooling system?

options.label: A
options.text: Its specific heat is too low

options.label: B
options.text: Its freezing point is too high

options.label: C
options.text: Its boiling point is too low

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of adding a solute to a solvent on the solution's freezing point?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the freezing point

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the freezing point

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the freezing point

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the type of solute

multiple-choice.question: What is the commonly used solution for a car's cooling system?

options.label: A
options.text: A 50/50 mixture of water and antifreeze

options.label: B
options.text: A 50/50 mixture of ethylene glycol and water

options.label: C
options.text: A 70/30 mixture of water and antifreeze

options.label: D
options.text: A 70/30 mixture of ethylene glycol and water

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not recommended to use a higher proportion of ethylene glycol in the cooling system?

options.label: A
options.text: It would decrease the freezing point too much

options.label: B
options.text: It would increase the boiling point too much

options.label: C
options.text: It would make the solution too viscous

options.label: D
options.text: It would make the solution's properties head towards those of ethylene glycol

title: How playing an instrument benefits your brain - Anita Collins

multiple-choice.question: What happens in the brain when a person listens to music?

options.label: A
options.text: Only one area of the brain is activated.

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple areas of the brain are activated, but only one at a time.

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple areas of the brain are activated simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: No areas of the brain are activated.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between listening to music and playing music in terms of brain activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Listening to music engages the brain's motor cortices, while playing music does not.

options.label: B
options.text: Playing music engages the brain's visual, auditory, and motor cortices, while listening to music only engages the auditory cortex.

options.label: C
options.text: Listening to music requires fine motor skills, while playing music does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Playing music requires only the left hemisphere of the brain, while listening to music requires both hemispheres.

multiple-choice.question: What is the corpus callosum, and how is it affected by playing music?

options.label: A
options.text: The corpus callosum is the part of the brain that controls motor skills, and playing music decreases its activity.

options.label: B
options.text: The corpus callosum is the bridge between the two hemispheres of the brain, and playing music increases its volume and activity.

options.label: C
options.text: The corpus callosum is the part of the brain that controls emotions, and playing music has no effect on it.

options.label: D
options.text: The corpus callosum is the part of the brain that controls memory, and playing music decreases its activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is executive function, and how is it related to playing music?

options.label: A
options.text: Executive function is the ability to plan and strategize, and playing music has no effect on it.

options.label: B
options.text: Executive function is the ability to pay attention to detail, and playing music decreases its activity.

options.label: C
options.text: Executive function is a category of interlinked tasks that includes planning, strategizing, and attention to detail, and playing music enhances its activity.

options.label: D
options.text: Executive function is the ability to remember things, and playing music has no effect on it.

multiple-choice.question: How do musicians' brains process memories compared to non-musicians' brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Musicians' brains process memories more slowly and less efficiently.

options.label: B
options.text: Musicians' brains process memories in the same way as non-musicians' brains.

options.label: C
options.text: Musicians' brains process memories more quickly and efficiently, using multiple tags such as conceptual, emotional, audio, and contextual tags.

options.label: D
options.text: Musicians' brains process memories only using one tag, such as a conceptual tag.

title: What happens when you get heat stroke? - Douglas J. Casa

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criterion for diagnosing exertional heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: A core body temperature greater than 38 degrees Celsius

options.label: B
options.text: A core body temperature greater than 40 degrees Celsius

options.label: C
options.text: A core body temperature less than 36 degrees Celsius

options.label: D
options.text: A heart rate above 120 beats per minute

multiple-choice.question: What is the most feasible and accurate way to assess core body temperature in cases of exertional heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral thermometer

options.label: B
options.text: Ear thermometer

options.label: C
options.text: Rectal thermometer

options.label: D
options.text: Armpit thermometer

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended treatment protocol for exertional heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: Transport first, cool second

options.label: B
options.text: Cool first, transport second

options.label: C
options.text: Call emergency services and wait for their arrival

options.label: D
options.text: Give the victim water to drink

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of exertional heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: Dehydration

options.label: B
options.text: Overexertion or high temperatures and humidity

options.label: C
options.text: Poor nutrition

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of sleep

multiple-choice.question: What is the prognosis for exertional heat stroke with proper care?

options.label: A
options.text: 50% survival rate

options.label: B
options.text: 75% survival rate

options.label: C
options.text: 90% survival rate

options.label: D
options.text: 100% survival rate

options.label: A
options.text: To become a more traditional art museum

options.label: B
options.text: To become a public forum for discourse on arts, culture, politics, and policy

options.label: C
options.text: To increase its collection of contemporary art

options.label: D
options.text: To become a more commercially successful museum

options.label: A
options.text: The Dome

options.label: B
options.text: The Bubble

options.label: C
options.text: The Forum

options.label: D
options.text: The Pavilion

options.label: B
options.text: Concrete

options.label: C
options.text: Steel

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Weekly

options.label: C
options.text: Twice a year, for one month at a time

title: Music and emotion through time - Michael Tilson Thomas

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's father's name, and how did it relate to the speaker's musical life?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker's father's name was Ted, and he was a music teacher.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker's father's name was Ted, and the speaker is still having a musical conversation with him.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker's father's name was not Ted, but he was a musician.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker's father's name was Ted, but he had no influence on the speaker's musical life.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are the two things that matter in music?

options.label: A
options.text: Melody and harmony

options.label: B
options.text: Rhythm and tempo

options.label: C
options.text: What and how

options.label: D
options.text: Theory and practice

multiple-choice.question: How did the development of notation change music, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: It made music more improvisational.

options.label: B
options.text: It enabled musicians to imagine music on a much vaster scale.

options.label: C
options.text: It limited the possibilities of music.

options.label: D
options.text: It made music more accessible to the general public.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the art of improvisation and the art of composition, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Improvisation is more spontaneous, while composition is more planned.

options.label: B
options.text: Improvisation is more emotional, while composition is more intellectual.

options.label: C
options.text: Improvisation is more instinctual, while composition is more intelligent.

options.label: D
options.text: Improvisation is more individual, while composition is more collaborative.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in sharing classical music with others?

options.label: A
options.text: To educate people about music theory

options.label: B
options.text: To promote the work of specific composers

options.label: C
options.text: To pass on the music and its emotional impact to others

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new generation of classical musicians

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's childhood dream?

options.label: A
options.text: To be a biologist and study plants.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To be a zoologist and study animals.

options.label: D
options.text: To be a geologist and study rocks.

options.label: A
options.text: DNA

options.label: B
options.text: Red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: Hemoglobin

options.label: D
options.text: Proteins

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Transgenesis

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The Hell Creek Project

options.label: B
options.text: The Dinosaur Project

options.label: C
options.text: The Fossil Project

options.label: D
options.text: The Jurassic Park Project

options.label: A
options.text: Atavism

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic modification

options.label: C
options.text: Transgenesis

options.label: D
options.text: Mutation

multiple-choice.question: In what year was the city where Hagia Sophia stands founded by Greek colonists?

options.label: A
options.text: 657 CE

options.label: B
options.text: 657 BCE

options.label: C
options.text: 415 CE

options.label: D
options.text: 532 CE

options.label: A
options.text: The Nika Riots

options.label: B
options.text: The Fourth Crusade

options.label: C
options.text: The Ottoman Empire's conquest of Constantinople

options.label: D
options.text: An earthquake

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They were built as architectural supports and for religious purposes

options.label: C

title: Inside the ant colony - Deborah M. Gordon

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way that ants communicate with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Through vocalizations

options.label: B
options.text: Through visual cues

options.label: C
options.text: Through touch, sound, and chemical signals

options.label: D
options.text: Through body language

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the queen ant in an ant colony?

options.label: A
options.text: To forage for food and defend the colony

options.label: B
options.text: To lay eggs and establish new colonies

options.label: C
options.text: To care for the young and maintain the nest

options.label: D
options.text: To coordinate the activities of the worker ants

multiple-choice.question: How do ants maximize their searching efficiency when exploring large areas?

options.label: A
options.text: By following a predetermined plan

options.label: B
options.text: By using visual cues to navigate

options.label: C
options.text: By changing their movement patterns based on individual interactions

options.label: D
options.text: By relying on a centralized leader

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pheromone trail left by ants when they find food?

options.label: A
options.text: To mark the location of the food for other ants

options.label: B
options.text: To warn other ants of potential threats

options.label: C
options.text: To signal the location of a new nesting site

options.label: D
options.text: To recruit other ants to follow the same path

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the practical applications of the search and retrieval methods used by ants?

options.label: A
options.text: Scheduling computing tasks

options.label: B
options.text: Optimizing Internet searches

options.label: C
options.text: Enabling groups of robots to search a minefield or a burning building collectively

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: How heavy is air? - Dan Quinn

multiple-choice.question: Why don't we notice the air around us most of the time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because air is a solid, not a fluid.

options.label: B
options.text: Because air is a fluid, but it's not dense enough to feel.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we commonly think of air as empty space.

options.label: D
options.text: Because air molecules are too small to exert a force.

multiple-choice.question: What is air pressure, and how is it exerted?

options.label: A
options.text: Air pressure is the force exerted by air molecules on the boundaries of a fluid, like water pressing against a glass.

options.label: B
options.text: Air pressure is the force exerted by air molecules on the floor and walls of a room.

options.label: C
options.text: Air pressure is the force exerted by air molecules on the human body, causing us to feel crushed.

options.label: D
options.text: Air pressure is the force exerted by air molecules on the atmosphere, causing weather changes.

multiple-choice.question: Why aren't we crushed by the weight of air in a typical school gym?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the air is pressing on the floor and walls, and the part that is pressing on us is pushed back by the pressure inside us.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the air is lighter than water, so it doesn't exert enough force.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the air molecules are too small to exert a significant force.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the air pressure is uniform, so we don't feel it.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when air pressure isn't uniform?

options.label: A
options.text: The air molecules stop moving, causing a lack of wind.

options.label: B
options.text: The air molecules push harder in one region of air than another, driving the air flow from the higher pressure region to the lower.

options.label: C
options.text: The air molecules become denser, causing the air to become heavier.

options.label: D
options.text: The air molecules become less dense, causing the air to become lighter.

multiple-choice.question: How do we breathe, and what role does air pressure play in this process?

options.label: A
options.text: We breathe by increasing the pressure in our lungs, allowing air to rush out.

options.label: B
options.text: We breathe by lowering the pressure in our lungs, allowing air to rush in.

options.label: C
options.text: We breathe by maintaining a uniform air pressure in our lungs, allowing air to flow in and out.

options.label: D
options.text: We breathe by ignoring air pressure altogether, and just using our diaphragm to expand and contract our lungs.

title: How to speak monkey: The language of cotton-top tamarins - Anne Savage

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way that Shakira, the cotton-top tamarin, communicates with her family and other tamarins?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a complex system of body language and facial expressions

options.label: B
options.text: Through a highly sophisticated language of 38 distinct calls based on variations of chirps and whistles

options.label: C
options.text: Through a series of clicks and chirrups

options.label: D
options.text: Through a complex system of scent markings

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Shakira's "E chirp" call?

options.label: A
options.text: To alert her family to the presence of food

options.label: B
options.text: To alert her family to the presence of a predator

options.label: C
options.text: To initiate play with her brother

options.label: D
options.text: To signal that she is approaching her family

multiple-choice.question: How do the initially modulated whistles used by Shakira change based on her proximity to her family?

options.label: A
options.text: They become louder when she is closer to her family

options.label: B
options.text: They become softer when she is closer to her family

options.label: C
options.text: They change pitch based on the proximity of Shakira to other members of her family

options.label: D
options.text: They remain the same regardless of her proximity to her family

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of Shakira's combination vocalization, which includes a chirp and a whistle?

options.label: A
options.text: To alert her family to the presence of food

options.label: B
options.text: To alert her family to the presence of another group of tamarins

options.label: C
options.text: To initiate play with her brother

options.label: D
options.text: To signal that she is approaching her family

multiple-choice.question: What is the current conservation status of the cotton-top tamarin, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Least Concern

options.label: B
options.text: Vulnerable

options.label: C
options.text: Endangered

options.label: D
options.text: Critically Endangered

options.text: The paper it is printed on

options.label: B
options.text: The government's gold or silver reserves

options.label: C
options.text: The number of bills in circulation

options.label: D

options.text: The Executive

options.label: B
options.text: The Legislative

options.label: C
options.text: The Judicial

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

options.label: B
options.text: The value of each bill would increase

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Inflation

options.label: C
options.text: Stagflation

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce business profits

options.label: C
options.text: To encourage economic growth

options.label: D

title: The quest to understand consciousness - Antonio Damasio

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Wonder" that the speaker refers to at the beginning of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The complexity of the human brain

options.label: B
options.text: The fact that we all woke up this morning with the return of our conscious mind

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of humans to create art and music

options.label: D
options.text: The power of self-talk in shaping our attitudes and behaviors

options.label: A
options.text: The grid of neurons has no effect on our mental experience

options.label: B
options.text: The grid of neurons determines the clarity of our mental images

options.label: C
options.text: A change in the grid of neurons can cause a warping of our mental experience

options.label: D
options.text: The grid of neurons only affects our peripheral vision

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain stem in generating a conscious mind, according to the speaker?

options.text: The brain stem is responsible for creating the contents of our minds

options.label: B
options.text: The brain stem provides the grounding for the self through its tight coupling with the body

options.label: C
options.text: The brain stem is only involved in regulating the body's physiological processes

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the autobiographical self, according to the speaker?

options.label: B
options.text: The level of self that is built on past memories and memories of future plans

options.label: C
options.text: The level of self that is responsible for regulating the body's physiological processes

options.label: D
options.text: The level of self that is only found in humans

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker think it is important to understand how the brain generates a conscious mind?

options.label: A
options.text: So that we can develop new treatments for diseases such as depression and Alzheimer's

options.label: B
options.text: So that we can better understand how to create artificial intelligence

options.label: C
options.text: So that we can gain a deeper understanding of human culture and society

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Soccer: the world's favorite game

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of football in Titie's life?

options.label: A
options.text: It's just a hobby she enjoys in her free time.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives her the drive to be who she is and have the goals she has.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a way for her to make a living.

options.label: D
options.text: It's something she's not very good at, but she likes to try.

multiple-choice.question: How did Titie manage to eat at school when she was growing up in poverty?

options.label: A
options.text: She would bring lunch from home.

options.label: B
options.text: She would buy food from the school cafeteria.

options.label: C
options.text: She would wait until they were writing a test, and then the students would pool their money to give to the student who scored the highest.

options.label: D
options.text: She would go hungry.

multiple-choice.question: Why does Titie share her story with others?

options.label: A
options.text: To get sympathy from others.

options.label: B
options.text: To show off her accomplishments.

options.label: C
options.text: To let others know that poverty cannot conquer them for the rest of their lives.

options.label: D
options.text: To get attention from others.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It's a school that teaches kids about soccer and physical education.

options.label: A
options.text: More money and resources.

options.label: B
options.text: Better education and job opportunities.

options.label: C
options.text: People uniting and working together.

options.label: D
options.text: More soccer matches and entertainment.

title: Why do honeybees love hexagons? - Zack Patterson and Andy Peterson

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why honeybees choose to construct their honeycomb cells in a hexagonal shape?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the most aesthetically pleasing shape.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows for the most efficient use of space and wax.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the strongest shape structurally.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the easiest shape to build.

title: Doodlers, unite! - Sunni Brown

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the common perception of doodling in the workplace or classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a valuable tool for processing information and solving problems.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a necessary skill for creative problem-solving.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a sign of intellectual weakness and a waste of time.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only useful for artistic purposes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's definition of doodling?

options.label: A
options.text: To make meaningless marks on paper.

options.label: B
options.text: To dawdle or waste time.

options.label: C
options.text: To make spontaneous marks to help yourself think.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a work of art.

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what is the effect of doodling on retaining verbal information?

options.label: A
options.text: People who doodle retain less information than those who do not doodle.

options.label: B
options.text: People who doodle retain the same amount of information as those who do not doodle.

options.label: C
options.text: People who doodle retain more information than those who do not doodle.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no correlation between doodling and retaining verbal information.

multiple-choice.question: What are the four learning modalities that doodling engages simultaneously?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Visual, auditory, kinesthetic, and emotional.

options.label: C
options.text: Visual, auditory, reading, and kinesthetic.

options.label: D
options.text: Reading, writing, kinesthetic, and emotional.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the potential benefit of leveraging doodling in situations where information density is high?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help to reduce stress and anxiety.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help to increase focus and retention of information.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help to improve artistic skills.

options.label: D
options.text: It can help to eliminate the need for verbal communication.

title: Unintended consequences - Edward Tenner

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the significance of the cultural explosion that occurred 40,000 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of the development of complex societies.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the time when music, art, and technology were born.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the period when humans first discovered fire.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the era when humans first developed language.

multiple-choice.question: What was the unintended consequence of the domestication of grains 10,000 years ago?

options.text: It led to better nutrition and longer lifespans.

options.label: B
options.text: It resulted in worse nutrition and possibly shorter lifespans.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant impact on human health.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the development of more complex societies.

options.label: B
options.text: It was coined by Thomas Edison to describe a flaw in his inventions.

options.label: C
options.text: It originated from the telegraphers of the mid-19th century who used it to describe mysterious problems in their systems.

options.label: D
options.text: It was popularized by Mark Twain in his writings about technology.

multiple-choice.question: What was the unintended consequence of adding extra lifeboats to the ship Eastland in 1915?

options.label: A
options.text: It made the ship more stable and safer.

options.label: B
options.text: It had no significant impact on the ship's stability.

options.label: C
options.text: It made the ship more unstable and contributed to its capsizing.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The fundamentals of space-time: Part 3 - Andrew Pontzen and Tom Whyntie

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of gravity on objects in space-time, according to Einstein's theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Gravity causes objects to move at constant speeds.

options.label: B
options.text: Gravity causes objects to accelerate, resulting in curved world lines.

options.label: C
options.text: Gravity has no effect on objects in space-time.

options.label: D
options.text: Gravity causes objects to move in straight lines.

multiple-choice.question: How does Einstein's theory of gravity differ from Isaac Newton's explanation?

options.label: A
options.text: Einstein's theory uses the concept of force and acceleration, while Newton's explanation uses curved space-time.

options.label: B
options.text: Einstein's theory uses curved space-time, while Newton's explanation uses the concept of force and acceleration.

options.label: C
options.text: Einstein's theory predicts the same phenomena as Newton's explanation.

options.label: D
options.text: Einstein's theory is based on quantum mechanics, while Newton's explanation is based on classical mechanics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the curvature of space-time becoming too large, such as in a black hole?

options.label: A
options.text: Einstein's equations become more accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: The curvature of space-time becomes smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: Einstein's equations collapse, requiring a new picture of space-time.

options.label: D
options.text: The curvature of space-time remains the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the wrinkles in the space-time material predicted by Einstein's theory?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Space-time waves

options.label: C
options.text: Curvature waves

options.label: D
options.text: Quantum waves

options.label: B
options.text: Indirect evidence from the polarization patterns of light left over from the Big Bang

options.label: C
options.text: The orbit of Mercury around the Sun

options.label: D
options.text: The deflection of light rays by massive objects

options.label: C
options.text: To produce proteins for digestion

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because having two copies provides redundancy in case one copy is mutated

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They divide more slowly

title: What is the World Wide Web?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the World Wide Web and the Internet?

options.label: A
options.text: The World Wide Web is a network of computers, while the Internet is a way of accessing information.

options.label: B
options.text: The World Wide Web is a way of accessing information, while the Internet is a network of computers.

options.label: C
options.text: The World Wide Web is used for email, while the Internet is used for file transfer.

options.label: D
options.text: The World Wide Web is used for conferencing, while the Internet is used for chatting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of a web host in the World Wide Web?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide Internet access to users.

options.label: B
options.text: To rent space on a web server for website owners.

options.label: C
options.text: To create website content for users.

options.label: D
options.text: To manage website addresses for users.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a domain name in the World Wide Web?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify a specific web server.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide a website address for users to access.

options.label: C
options.text: To translate web languages into a graphic interface.

options.label: D
options.text: To link multiple web pages together.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of hyperlinks in the World Wide Web?

options.label: A
options.text: They allow users to access websites in a linear fashion.

options.label: B
options.text: They enable web browsers to translate web languages into a graphic interface.

options.label: C
options.text: They connect multiple web pages within a website or redirect users to other websites.

options.label: D
options.text: They provide a way for users to communicate with each other.

options.label: B

options.label: C
